lines.text: Enter WARWICK, the Mayor of Coventry, two Messengers, and others upon the walls

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Where is the post that came from valiant Oxford? How far hence is thy lord, mine honest fellow?

lines.speaker: first messenger
lines.text: By this at Dunsmore, marching hitherward.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: How far off is our brother Montague? Where is the post that came from Montague?

lines.speaker: second messenger
lines.text: By this at Daintry, with a puissant troop.
Enter SIR JOHN SOMERVILLE

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Say, Somerville, what says my loving son? And, by thy guess, how nigh is Clarence now?

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: At Southam I did leave him with his forces, And do expect him here some two hours hence.
Drum heard

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Then Clarence is at hand, I hear his drum.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: It is not his, my lord; here Southam lies: The drum your honour hears marcheth from Warwick.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Who should that be? belike, unlook'd-for friends.

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: They are at hand, and you shall quickly know. March: flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Go, trumpet, to the walls, and sound a parle.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: See how the surly Warwick mans the wall!

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: O unbid spite! is sportful Edward come? Where slept our scouts, or how are they seduced, That we could hear no news of his repair?

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Now, Warwick, wilt thou ope the city gates, Speak gentle words and humbly bend thy knee, Call Edward king and at his hands beg mercy? And he shall pardon thee these outrages.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Nay, rather, wilt thou draw thy forces hence, Confess who set thee up and pluck'd thee own, Call Warwick patron and be penitent? And thou shalt still remain the Duke of York.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: I thought, at least, he would have said the king; Or did he make the jest against his will?

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Is not a dukedom, sir, a goodly gift?

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Ay, by my faith, for a poor earl to give: I'll do thee service for so good a gift.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: 'Twas I that gave the kingdom to thy brother.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Why then 'tis mine, if but by Warwick's gift.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Thou art no Atlas for so great a weight: And weakling, Warwick takes his gift again; And Henry is my king, Warwick his subject.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: But Warwick's king is Edward's prisoner: And, gallant Warwick, do but answer this: What is the body when the head is off?

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Alas, that Warwick had no more forecast, But, whiles he thought to steal the single ten, The king was slily finger'd from the deck! You left poor Henry at the Bishop's palace, And, ten to one, you'll meet him in the Tower.

lines.speaker: edward
lines.text: 'Tis even so; yet you are Warwick still.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Come, Warwick, take the time; kneel down, kneel down: Nay, when? strike now, or else the iron cools.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: I had rather chop this hand off at a blow, And with the other fling it at thy face, Than bear so low a sail, to strike to thee.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Sail how thou canst, have wind and tide thy friend, This hand, fast wound about thy coal-black hair Shall, whiles thy head is warm and new cut off, Write in the dust this sentence with thy blood, 'Wind-changing Warwick now can change no more.'
Enter OXFORD, with drum and colours

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: O cheerful colours! see where Oxford comes!

lines.speaker: oxford
lines.text: Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaster!
He and his forces enter the city

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: The gates are open, let us enter too.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: So other foes may set upon our backs. Stand we in good array; for they no doubt Will issue out again and bid us battle: If not, the city being but of small defence, We'll quickly rouse the traitors in the same.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: O, welcome, Oxford! for we want thy help.
Enter MONTAGUE with drum and colours

lines.speaker: montague
lines.text: Montague, Montague, for Lancaster!
He and his forces enter the city

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Thou and thy brother both shall buy this treason Even with the dearest blood your bodies bear.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: The harder match'd, the greater victory: My mind presageth happy gain and conquest.
Enter SOMERSET, with drum and colours

lines.speaker: somerset
lines.text: Somerset, Somerset, for Lancaster!
He and his forces enter the city

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Two of thy name, both Dukes of Somerset, Have sold their lives unto the house of York; And thou shalt be the third if this sword hold.
Enter CLARENCE, with drum and colours

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: And lo, where George of Clarence sweeps along, Of force enough to bid his brother battle; With whom an upright zeal to right prevails More than the nature of a brother's love! Come, Clarence, come; thou wilt, if Warwick call.

lines.speaker: clarence
lines.text: Father of Warwick, know you what this means? Look here, I throw my infamy at thee I will not ruinate my father's house, Who gave his blood to lime the stones together, And set up Lancaster. Why, trow'st thou, Warwick, That Clarence is so harsh, so blunt, unnatural, To bend the fatal instruments of war Against his brother and his lawful king? Perhaps thou wilt object my holy oath: To keep that oath were more impiety Than Jephthah's, when he sacrificed his daughter. I am so sorry for my trespass made That, to deserve well at my brother's hands, I here proclaim myself thy mortal foe, With resolution, wheresoe'er I meet thee-- As I will meet thee, if thou stir abroad-- To plague thee for thy foul misleading me. And so, proud-hearted Warwick, I defy thee, And to my brother turn my blushing cheeks. Pardon me, Edward, I will make amends: And, Richard, do not frown upon my faults, For I will henceforth be no more unconstant.
Taking his red rose out of his hat

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Now welcome more, and ten times more beloved, Than if thou never hadst deserved our hate.

lines.speaker: gloucester
lines.text: Welcome, good Clarence; this is brotherlike.

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: O passing traitor, perjured and unjust!

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: What, Warwick, wilt thou leave the town and fight? Or shall we beat the stones about thine ears?

lines.speaker: warwick
lines.text: Alas, I am not coop'd here for defence! I will away towards Barnet presently, And bid thee battle, Edward, if thou darest.

lines.speaker: king edward the fourth
lines.text: Yes, Warwick, Edward dares, and leads the way. Lords, to the field; Saint George and victory! So, lie thou there: die thou, and die our fear; For Warwick was a bug that fear'd us all. Now, Montague, sit fast; I seek for thee, That Warwick's bones may keep thine company.
Exeunt King Edward and his company. March. Warwick and his company follow
